lecture_title: EXPERIMENT NO. 3: Determine HCl concentration with standard NaOH

questions.question_text: What is the main aim of EXPERIMENT NO. 3?
options: To prepare a standard solution of NaOH
To determine the concentration of HCl solution using a standard NaOH solution
To study the properties of different indicators
To standardize HCl solution using a primary standard solid

questions.question_text: Titration is a technique used in Volumetric Analysis to determine the concentration of an unknown solution by:
options: Controlled slow addition of a titrant until neutralization
Observing its color change upon heating
Dissolving a known mass of solute in it

questions.question_text: What is the 'equivalence point' in a titration?
options: When the concentration of [H+] equals the concentration of [OH-]
When half of the titrant has been added
The point at which the solution becomes turbid

questions.question_text: What is the 'endpoint' in a titration?
options: The point where [H+] = [OH-], without color change
The point where the reaction begins
The point indicated by a change in color of the solution, signifying equivalence has been achieved
The initial reading on the burette

questions.question_text: Phenolphthalein (Ph-Ph) indicator is colorless in acidic medium and changes to what color in a basic medium?
What color change does Methyl Orange (M-O) indicator show when moving from an acidic to an alkaline/base medium?
What is the chemical equation for the reaction between sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and hydrochloric acid (HCl)?
In this experiment (HCl unknown, NaOH standard), what happens to the solution's color at the endpoint when using Phenolphthalein?
Which piece of glassware is primarily used to deliver the titrant (e.g., standard NaOH solution) with precision during titration?
What is the first step in the procedure for titration, regarding the burette?
options: Fill it with the unknown solution
Wash it with water and then with distilled water
Record the initial volume after filling it halfway

questions.question_text: How much hydrochloric acid solution is added to the conical flask for titration according to the procedure?
options: The volume measured by the burette

questions.question_text: Why is a white sheet placed under the conical flask during titration?
options: To better observe the discoloration (color change) of the solution
To reflect light and speed up the reaction

questions.question_text: How should the sodium hydroxide solution be added from the burette during titration?
options: Continuously and slowly, with shaking of the conical flask
Drop by drop from the very beginning
Only after heating the conical flask

questions.question_text: What action should be taken immediately when the solution in the conical flask turns pink (using phenolphthalein) and stays pink?
options: Continue adding NaOH for another 1 mL
Heat the solution to see if the color disappears

questions.question_text: Why is the titration typically repeated three times?
options: To use up all the reagents
To ensure accuracy and obtain an average volume
Because the first two are usually practice runs
To allow the indicator to fully mix

questions.question_text: Which formula is used to calculate the unknown concentration in this acid-base titration?

Discussion Q5: If 0.1M HCl is used to titrate 2mL of unknown NaOH, and average HCl volumes used are 9.8mL, 18mL, and 27mL respectively for three trials, what is the approximate concentration of NaOH? (Assume these are individual trials for 2mL NaOH each time, and average the V(HCl))
Discussion Q6: If 5 mL of HCl solution requires an average of 8.0 mL of 0.1 M NaOH for titration, what is the concentration of the HCl solution?
Discussion Q7: If 2 mL of HCl solution required an average of 7.3 mL of 1.2 M NaOH for titration, what is the concentration of the HCl solution?
Why should the conical flask be shaken continuously during titration?
options: To prevent the indicator from settling
To ensure thorough mixing of reactants for a complete and rapid reaction
To speed up the color change at the endpoint
